comments.body: ... Is this not just asking for more drama?

Word it without use of the bdfl title/wording? 

Other idea is for the purpose of coc we all take turns as chair of the steering committee with this responsibility when steering cannot reach a decision with a clear majority which should be very rare and hopefully never.

Just word it more neutral. John can be the tie breaker but the phrasing is just not good... "BDFL" sounds non-democratic and anti-communal. What we want is for John to support the steering committee, not be a dictator.

Maybe Martin Odersky's role in the [Scala Improvement Process](https://docs.scala-lang.org/sips/sip-submission.html) and migration to Scala 3 is a good analogy, where he has a veto on decisions made by the committee? Hard to argue it is so terrible if it is used for governance of Scala itself.

"BDFL" is a safe-guard mechanism that would hopefully never be exercised, but it's important to state the expectations upfront.

If the steering committee wants to do one thing, and I want to do another, and we are unable to resolve our differences of opinion, what happens? We have to do something.

As projects become successful, they are subject to hostile takeovers. I saw that with Lars taking over the Scalaz project from Tony. I would not invest in this project like I have (untold hours and significant financial expense) if that were a remote possibility.

Having a BDFL will always rub people the wrong way, but it's a protection against things that matter to me very deeply—things that my founding and participation in this project have always been contingent on.

If I ever abuse BDFL for any reason, then it will be manifestly obvious, and I'd hope everyone I count as a friend would call me on that. I also hope that my long track record of keeping cool in any situation and never lashing out at anyone, no matter what they've done to me personally, will give people the confidence and trust they need to move forward.

Odersky himself is mentioned on the [Wikipedia page for BDFL](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benevolent_dictator_for_life) along with a lot of open source figures, so I don’t think it’s unreasonable John being BDFL for ZIO.
Agree with @jdegoes lets with BDFL I say

I agree that the title "BDFL" has an anti-communal scent to it. But, I also trust John's ability to navigate conflict responsibly and to put ego aside. I also trust his ability to take criticism should we feel he abuses this position.

I had originally suggested this clause both for the above and because I am wary of hostile takeovers. Finally - I don't think we will need to exercise this clause, having 7-8 very able personas on board on the committee.

@iravid After reading the wikipedia entry it seems like a good fit, but... it did sound like asking for drama until I learned that is an already estabilished term. Perhaps a quote from wikiepedia explaining the term or rephrasing to something more neutral, like `Founding Father` would serve us better in getting the "right message" across?

@iravid 
> ## Founding Father
> 
> In addition to the above the title Founding Father of ZIO project belongs to John De Goes (@jdegoes)
> indefinitely, owing to him originating the project and continued investments in it. While John adheres to
>  the same code of conduct as everyone else, he is entitled to override moderation decisions made by
> the steering comittee.
```

comments.body:
I would suggest if we generalize this:
```suggestion
communication channels. If the code of conduct is violated by any one, please contact one of the moderators immediately. 
```
or we can mention the discouraged behaviors that are mentioned in the CoC 
What do you think?

I think the previous one is less formulaic and IMHO a bit more useful, because while violation of a CoC is a *proxy* for harmful behavior, harm itself is primary. We shouldn't think about violating a CoC as an offense in itself, but rather about CoC being a prescription for the community on what constitutes and how to deal with harmful behavior.
Yes, you're right while it is mentioned that ZIO follows CoC it should be clear to respect all the statement there and the sentence like before makes sense too :).
